instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3635: What is 820-3635? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
History: It had some minor issue on PP3V42 and then it was working good. Suddenly shut itself off, then was working day after and again shut off. Turn on, shut off. I found some solder balls around <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>, but they could be a result of previous technician work since I see that CPU, SMC and BIOS were reworked on. (CPU and SMC missing glue, BIOS probably replaced). However not looks burned on the board. It's actually pretty clean.

PP3V42, PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> present. 

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> not present. Barely 0.008V.

DCPS shows around 105mA draw upon boot.

Seems like CPU is not being told to turn on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board?? these boards have a common fault where "<CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/20/30" will stop working, you can try to replace all FDMF6808 with new FDMF6708.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: Sorry, crucial mistake. Board is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Air 11". Can it be changed it title somehow?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Do you get 24MHz at Y1915?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: The CPU has been reworked???RUNNNN lol waste of time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0.069V
<SIGNAL>SYSPWROK_R</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V

Y1915: (don't have an oscilloscope)
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK24M_XTALOUT_R</SIGNAL> - 0.34V
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK34M_XTALIN</SIGNAL> - 0.42V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Strange to have S0 voltages without <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal.
Confirm if this is the case...
Check if all voltages involved in <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> generation are present.
You can start removing <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
You mean <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>?

I'm using DCPS with original head charger if that matters.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Yes, <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.
I was looking wrong schematic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>:
pin 1 - 0.96V
pin 2 - 0.23V
pin 3 - 0.23V
pin 4 - 0.07V
pin 5 - 0.81V
pin 6 - 0.27V
pin 7 - 0.81V
pin 8 - 0.23V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Remove it directly.
And check other resistors connected to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is now removed:
pin 1 - 3.2V (<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> comes here, should be 1.5V, right?)
pin 2 - 0V
pin 3 - 0V
pin 4 - 0.07V
pin 5 - 1.09V
pin 6 - 3.3V
pin 7 - 1.06V
pin 8 - 0V

Other resistors connected to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> measure correctly.

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.600 resistance (12.5kOhms)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
I found <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> pin 6 looked like it has some extra heat absorbed since there was a solder ball there. Removed <CHIP>U7870</CHIP>, laptop starts, draws around 550mA. Question mark on the screen, probably would boot into OSX if I plugged in external drive.

When I measure its' voltages:
pin 1 - 3.2V then drops to 2.9V.
pin 2 - NC
pin 3 - 3.3V
pin 4 - 3.3V
pin 5 - GND
pin 6 - 1.8V

When <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> was installed, on pin 6 (<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>) I had around 3V if I remember. Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>) still measures high since it is around 3V, instead of 1.5V?

<CHIP>U7870</CHIP> is 1.5V S0 LDO. So it seems that there is a problem on the <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: Continuity test showed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> connected to <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>. Resistance to each other 13 Ohms. Since CPU was reworked... I guess it could only be connected under CPU because pins are next to each other?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Check for short between pins 1-4 of <CHIP>U7870</CHIP>.
If yes, remove <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> and check again between its pads on the board.
If you still get 3V at pad 1, then you have a problem with PCH, or some balls molten under it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> is removed. Pin 1 has 3.3V there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message: Is the board fully working in this case?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
I have not idea. It boots, but I haven?t checked further. 
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is responsible for some audio stuff as far as I can see. 
Probably it should work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Disconnect LIO flex and check again <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> line.
Overvoltage can come from audio section of LIO board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3635</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 105mA current draw upon boot, no CPU voltage
threads.message:
Unfortunately, still connected to each other after LIO flex was removed.

In order to make stuff work, I'd probably have to replace resistors with other values so that it brings down voltage on certain rails needed for Audio stuff?
